text: We were their for my husbands birthday celebration. Nice restuarent, nice service. But whats all that when your dinner wasnt what you expected. My mistake was not looking at dinner menu first. Way overpriced, didnt have steak sauce, at all. We were still hungry after no ribeye, no, sirloin, nothing but half burnt, shoulder steak. Over cooked fries. I will never go here again. Advise anyone else not to. At your own risk. Nothing under $25 but food was horrible. I didnt want to make a scene but i wanted to let people know from this review. When i dont usually take time to do this. See all the positive comments. But no dont take the risk. Look at menu, which is small portions and not good. Eat first if u go. The bill came $175 way overpriced. For no food on the plate. Dont mind paying if its  worth it.

name: Jared Shaw
text: Nice place and service great. However disappointed in the food quality.

name: Brad Seehawer
text:
Having almost completed the rounds of Montgomery's fine dining scene, the deciding factor for me is in the aspirations of the kitchen. I rarely have a problem with service (to include here), but when I'm paying $30 for an entree, I want to know some creativity and skill has been put into it. I think Central accomplishes enough to warrant it, though - as always - not without a few faults.

I like the idea of the snacks menu - a lighter portion than an appetizer. And the pickled vegetables were about as good as I was expecting, with a mason jar filled with green tomatoes, radishes, green beans, and asparagus. The brined worked into different vegetables with different degrees of effectiveness, resulting in some lightly-pickled green beans and some green tomatoes that were so sour and overpowering with juniper (or whatever spice tastes like a mouthful of potpourri) that I had to struggle to get it down.

The redfish I ordered was served without skin and cooked reasonably well. It was a drier fish, which put to good use the sauce and ragout with which it was served. Or "ragout", rather - I don't know if the disparate bits of corn, mushroom, and leek were tied together well enough to call it one cohesive item. The corn emulsion was a little better - a buttery corny sauce that did the job.

The open kitchen and the individual components of my meal were enough to make me wonder how they might treat that pork belly appetizer. Or at the very least, allow me to recommend it for someone that's looking for a decent meal in the limited downtown area.

name: Chris Robinson
text: Good food, great service, but horrible seating. With reservations on Valentine's, we were seated at the worst table in the place. We were at the door and in the direct service line from the kitchen. The restaurant was more than half empty during our entire visit. I had higher expectations based off word around town and for the price ($135.00 for two), I won't go back.

text: Posting this late as our visit was late in September. The filet was one of the best I’ve had, simply divine.

name: UnbiasedReport
text: I've been here with my company once. Food was pretty good. We stayed in a reserved room. Beautiful decor. I came back with my husband later to price their event room. THAT wasn't the problem. The problem was when my husband and I were out on date night, we were originally headed to SAZAs around the corner, but saw Central first. So we checked it out. What an utter disappointment to be told there was no table in the dining room available for dinner. I looked around. 80% of the tables were empty. I told the host that. She said they are expecting a large reservation to show up and that we can use the bar, it's the same. My husband and I went to the bar. I was already feeling unwelcome and offended by the price. I'm sorry, but I think we were shoo'ed away to the bar. I understand reservations, but if you saw that situation, you would say the same. There's no way the whole dining room was reserved. Why...would you allow someone to hinder your regular guests with the party they are having quote on quote instead of requiring them reserve a room upstairs? I have never been so offended. I don't trust the integrity of this restaurant. This is what I told my husband. We left and went to SAZAs, it was the best decision! They were friendly, staffed, affordable, welcoming. It was our first time there too. Based on the customer service alone and food quality, we'll be at SAZAs again!

name: Ni
text: Went for lunch.  Service was good and food overall tasted fine.  My issue is two fold.  First is the hamburger.  Apparently medium comes out well done.  I'm guessing they don't care because they smother so much Mayo and sweet sauce on it you can't taste much else.  I expect more from a high class restaurant with a $14 hamburger.  Second issue was my side dish.  I asked if I could substitute anything for the fries trying to be healthier.  I was told yes and given several options.  I chose a side salad.  What the waiter didn't tell me was it's an extra $3 for giving up my fries for a small bowl of iceberg lettuce with a little tomato and cucumber that probably cost them $0.30.  This is very frustrating trying to eat healthy on a budget.  To summarize, bad overly expensive salad + overcooked hamburger for $20= never again.  I don't understand how this place got so many good reviews.

resp.text: We apologize your dining experience was less than stellar. We pride ourselves on being an upscale casual restaurant dedicated to sourcing local food and providing a sophisticated yet relaxed dining atmosphere. We do hope you come again and we have a second chance to correct any issues you had. If you would like to speak to management, please email us at info@central129coosa.com and a member of management will be in touch to discuss the matter. We are always open to learning about opportunities for improvement and reflection. We hope for the chance to serve you again soon.

name: Kimberly Cole Zemke
text: They say to find a really good restaurant: "Follow the crowd".  If that old adage is true then we should have left when we first arrived.  You show me a self proclaimed GOURMET restaurant with only two couples there on a Friday night at eight and I will show you a not so great place to grab dinner.  My son suggested Central and he loves fine dining.   Why shouldn't he, we have taken him all over the World.  He has eaten at Gargantua in Frankfort, Germany and Jules Verne and 58 Tour Eiffel both of which are on the Eiffel Tower in Paris, France.  The food was really not the problem some of it was actually good, however the service was terrible.  Our waitress seemed completely bored and disenchanted with us.   Yawning at us as she told us the specials.  We started out with the cheese, meat and fruit platter and she simply could not remember the names of the cheeses.  She was not going to present me with a lemon for my tea for love nor money.  I practically begged three times.  I tried to be as nice as possible .  My husband finally got my lemon from the bar.  I had to ask twice for a refill.  If I am paying $32,00 for a fish entree plus a dessert and appetizer then I deserve a refill.  Right?  The waitress then seemed to feel she deserved a larger tip than twenty two dollars which was ten percent.  The food:  My husband got the Rabbit.  It was delicious.  I had a taste and it was as good as any rabbit we had in Paris which was always delicious.  I had the Amberjack with Hoppin Joe and Crawfish Succatash.  The Hoppin Joe was delicious with the crawfish but the fish was a tad dry and a bit bland.  It was a very nice size of fish.  Kenny got the Bricken Chicken which he said was only average.  The Whiskey Collards were delicious as were the Fried Brussel Sprouts.  My  son got the Short Ribs which he seemed to enjoy.  The sides were delicious and seemed to be better than the entrees.   All in all the beautiful decor made up for part of it.

name: Bill McGinley
text:
Was recently in Montgomery and searching out the best spots...one of the first on the short list was Central

Central is a lovely place downtown I guess in what they would call a historic district, just a short walk to the river. The place was just amazing from the moment you walk in; the staff were super friendly and attentive

Right away it was a bit warm in there even for winter, they have a huge wood fired oven that many dishes are prepared in - albeit beautiful, it throws off a ton of heat

We started with baked oysters and the cornbread and sausage. I have to say, I didn't care for the oysters - and the cornbread was good, but not great, kind of dense and heavy. The sausage was good..but not remarkable

They boasted using local ingredients where possible - and especially from the gulf. I had the Fra Diavolo, which I was excited about because it was supposed to have Gulf Redfish, Scallops and Shrimp. It was good, but ultimately disappointing. The shrimp were very small...like almost salad shrimp and when they're cooked they become like hard rubber chew toys. The scallops were delicious - and I forgot there was even red fish in there until I saw some small flakes of it floating around in it. But the shrimp were the real crime here...missed an opportunity to showcase the wonderful gulf shrimp I had come to expect.

My friend had gotten the wood fired filet...which I had forgone in favor of wanting to sample the local Gulf offering. OMG - the filet was heavenly. Just delicious is was soft and buttery, it had a nice outer char with wonderful beef flavor and the smoky fire baked right in, and it made my eyes roll back in my head...so good! - So yea...I had some real food envy going on.

I ate the scallops out of mine and was done with it. Central is a solid offering - I have a feeling I will be back in Montgomery again and I will be back to Central. Not everything was a hit - and it wasn't perfect but it was very good and I feel worth trying other things on the menu - this is a first class operation downtown and worth a visit.

text:
I enjoyed a delicious dinner last night; seasonal baby tomatoes with burata cheese which was creamy yummy with a tart pickled tomatoe and sweet red tomatoes. For the main course I ordered the seafood pot pie which had a flaky puff pastry topping with crawfish and other delicious fish in a veloute which was delicious.

The presentation was different and creative and the bar clientele very friendly. I highly recommend this restaurant.

name: Jeff Taylor
text:
Service was really good...best ive had in long time.  Drink menu and beer selection is really good.  Mixed drinks are $10 and craft drafts are $6 with bottles at $3.50.  Wine list is pretty extensive but we didn't try any.

Menu is not a standard type menu so if you go be willing to try new things.  We tried the oyster appetizers as well as the burnt end lettuce wraps.  Both were good but the oysters lacked any depth of taste besides the oysters themselves.

For the main course we had braised rabbit carbonara with peaches and some eggplant rollatinis.  The carbonara was unbelievably good...The peaches were raw in small pieces and really add a hint of sweetness.  The eggplant was good but spicy and not indicated on the menu as such.  Most items were $25 - $30 per plate, but the quality is very high.

Dessert list sounded like it was laid out by a 6 yr old as everything has cereal added to it, but don't let that scare you off.  The desserts are delicate and delectable and worth the adventure.  We tried the doughnut bread pudding with fruity pepples and the coco puff cheesecake.  Neither were overly sweet...

My husband and I both had their Hereford Braised Shortrib. The meat was flavorful and tender and went well with the sweet potatoes and crispy brussel sprouts. Dessert for the birthday boy was on the house and he definitely enjoyed his Creme Brulee with ice cream. They also has complimentary valet parking.
